Nikolai, there is actually an interesting alternative solution to this prob=
lem:  Instead of using a counter for the innovation number, you can use a v=
ery precise time stamp.  The time stamp does not guarantee that some uninte=
nded matches might happen (e.g. if two separate computers in different plac=
es somehow create a connection at the exact same millisecond since 1970 on =
their clocks), but it makes them very unlikely.  

If I recall right, I thi=
nk this idea is implemented in Dance Evolution:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/da=
nce_evolution/

We were worried that people might want to trade dancer geno=
mes that they evolved among each other and that it would confuse people tha=
t they could not mate with each other (since they are likely from completel=
y separate runs on different machines).  So I think we did start using time=
-stamp based innovations numbers.

Another option is pure-random innovation=
 numbers, which would also work, but would lose the nice property that inno=
vations numbers record the order that innovations occurred.

ken
